item.description:
"The Doctor and Sabbath are both looking for the scattered remnants of the Elementals, the Lords of Time who never existed. Chief among these artifacts is a black sun, the EYE."

"He who controls the EYE controls the new dynasty of Time Lords for the universe. But while the Eighth Doctor has looked without for the Eye, he has not tried to first look WITHIN."

"The TARDIS was once infinite, but now only a small part of its interior is accessible. And Fitz is hearing strange sounds behind the unusual walls that have partitioned the TARDIS' interior. And now a door to the mysterious cloister room has opened. Could the EYE have been in their all the while? But one challenge stands in the Doctor's way of
exploring the cloister room and unveiling its secrets: SABBATH!"

"One Player plays the Doctor. His goal is to move from the CONSOLE ROOM to the CLOISTER ROOM. The other plays Sabbath. 
His goal is to prevent the Doctor from reaching the cloister room."

"The eighth doctor has lost his memory. He has a whole new band of enemies. One player plays Sabbath. The other is the good doctor."

"There are three decks: One for the doctor, one for Sabbath and an 'elemental' artifact deck."

The winner is the player who obtains the most elemental artifact cards.

name.value: Doctor Who: The Keys of Chronos

item.description:
"The old Time Lords are gone, and many races are competing to take their place as the Lords of Time. In order to forge a new Gallifrey and a new order of the Lords of Time, the Eighth Doctor must scour time and space to recover the six keys of Chronos. This will insure the new Gallifrey protection from its rivals, and bring order to all time and space."

At the start of the game, each player is dealt six Mission Cards. The six cards identify the six keys that the player is searching for. The first player to obtain all six keys named on his Mission Cards wins the game.

name.value: Doctor Who: The Lords of Time

item.description:
"Gallifrey has been removed from space and time, but nature abhors a vacuum. It is up to the inheritors of their legacy to forge a new Gallifrey and a new order of the Lords of Time."

"Up to four players may play this game. There are four sides: The Eighth Doctor from Earth, Sabbath from the Moon, and Empress Miranda from the Throne World of the Universal Empire, and the cyborg Silver who has escaped exile from the Planet A2756."

The first player to reach the New Gallifrey space in the center of the board by exact count wins the game.

name.value: Doctor Who: Remnant of the Daleks

item.description:
"The last of the Daleks have invaded the TARDIS Console Room. And it’s up to the Eighth Doctor, Romana and K9 to stop them from taking over the TARDIS. Whoever controls the TARDIS controls all of Causality."

Each player has three units. The Doctor player has the Eighth Doctor, Romana, and K9. The Dalek player has three Daleks.

The conflict takes place in four TARDIS areas: the Console Room, Library, Clock Garden, and Altar Room. Each player has a card deck which is used to randomly determine movement between the four areas. The cards are also used to resolve combat.

The object of the game is to defeat all opposing units.

SMART stands for Simple Miniatures Adventures Rules and Tactics.

"These miniature rules may be used for fantasy or medieval miniature war gaming, but can easily be adapted to any genre. These rules were inspired from Little Armies by H. G. Wells and Kreigspiel."

The rules are described as being suitable for any scale from 100:1 to 1:1.

A skirmish level science-fiction miniatures game based on the short story "A Prayer Answered Just in Time" published in Gateway magazine.

"Nestled in the six extra dimensions of the Calabi-Yau Manifold (which is a plane higher than the four spatial dimensions of Hyperspace) every event in space in time meets with the Interface. The Interface of Time is a great ten dimensional construct which consists of archways that lead to any world at any point in that planet’s history. Humans can only perceive the first three spatial dimensions of the Interface. Thus it allegorically appears to them as a contemplative cloister with seemingly endless arcades leading forth from a monumental courtyard."

"In this game one player plays the mysterious Virtue and his human friends. The other player plays the infamous Vice and his company of evil time travelers." The object of the game is to destroy the opponent's four warriors.

A science fiction card game based on the Lensman stories. It is an expansion designed to be used with the Rebel Space rules.

The game pits the Galactic Patrol of the First Galaxy (Milky Way) against the Baskonian Pirates of the Second Galaxy (Andromeda). The Galactic Patrol player has a deck of 65 cards and the Baskonian player has a deck of 63 cards. The object of the game is to reduce the opponent's deck to zero cards.

Expands:

 Rebel Space

A science fiction card game of the Rebels versus the Imperials. Despite the generic card descriptions, it is clear that this game is inspired by the original Star Wars saga. Thus you have cards like the Smuggler, Converted Freighter, and Alien Companion, as well as the Young Protagonist, Wise Mentor, Princess, and Robot Sidekick.

Each side starts with a unique deck of 65 cards. The object of the game is to reduce the opponent's deck to zero cards.

Expanded by:

 Lensman

A game of battling giant robots (Meks) and the pilots who ride in them (Mercs).

The rules describe nine pre-designed Meks. Players can also design their own Meks using the chassis, weapon, and other Mek systems specifications given in the rules. Mek pilots are individually rated for experience and skills.

The game is played on a 3x3 grid. Each square is marked with a terrain type as specified by scenario. The game comes with six scenarios.

"A fantasy warfare card game for 2-6 players"

The object of the game is to capture the Territory Tokens of the other players, representing conquest of their lands.

The game uses a custom deck of 130 cards. Each player starts with five Territory Tokens. Tokens may be won and lost as a result of battles battles out through card play.

link.value: Warmeister 2: The Battle of Plentymore Field

item.description:
The players represent various elements of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) seeking to assassinate Fidel Castro back in the fifties and sixties.

The game uses a custom deck of 57 cards. There are seven types of cards: Method, Conspiracy, Location, Save, Event, Propaganda, and Spy.

The players attempt to play melds of cards of the same type. Once you have three melds in play (one each for Method, Conspiracy, and Location), you may make an Assassination Attempt die roll to see if you kill Castro. If the roll is not successful, you lose some or all of your melds and the game continues.

Save and Event cards can be used to require an opponent to discard a meld. Propaganda cards allow a player to draw additional cards. Spy cards allow you to look at an opponent's cards and steal one.

"Winning: Be the first player to Assassinate Castro. If Castro is not killed after the players have gone through the deck twice then Castro survives and all the players lose."

A simple game of individual combat with firearms, in the style of first-person shooter computer games.

"The objective of the game is to blow the bajesus out of your enemies. You take turns moving and shooting. Each turn, you get two actions. Actions are usually either moving, shooting, aiming or reloading. Each of these usually cost one action."

"The Evil Mad Scientist Doctor Herr Guffin has left his assistants (Igor, Igor, Igor and lest we forget, Igor) in charge of his experiments while he goes to a convention on 'Evil Inventions and the Applications in Modern Society'."

"The experiment in particular is a machine he designed to breed a better rat (because the kids these days had gone and invented a better mousetrap). It is a mixture of mechanical and electronic feeder/torturing device."

"The object of the player (called Igor) is to have his favourite rat the biggest by the time the master returns."

"This involves making sure that toggles tilt the pipes in the machine such that the food pellets go to the player's rat - and avoiding/rotating the shocking motor such that the other rats are shocked (which causes them to lose food pellets, probably through vomiting)."

"There are event cards as well (things like Cardiac Arrest - fattest rat gets a chronic heart attack and dies)."

"A simulation of the War in Heaven from John Milton's Paradise Lost. In it, the forces of Satan fight the forces of God in a battle for control of Heaven before the Son defeats them and they are cast out of Heaven and into Hell."

The game is based on Books V and VI of Paradise Lost. The Satan player must destroy a certain number of Heaven's forces to win the game. The Force of Good player wins by preventing Satan from achieving his victory conditions.

"Generic Rules for Combat in any scale or era."

A universal and generic wargaming system for recreating battles from all eras, and from fiction, using a hex map, counters, and dice.

Unit stats are included for World War I, World War II, Napoleonic campaigns, Feudal Japan, the Middle Ages, and science fiction spacecraft.

In addition, there are army lists for Middle Earth conflicts as depicted in Lord of the Rings and Star Wars spaceship battles.

A generic rules set for recreating ancient battles on a variety of scales.

"The basic concept is to be able to have: Relatively quick battles with 20-30 units to a side. A minimum of record keeping. Easy set up. A very simple rules-system, easily learned, and easily modified."

Contains Army Lists for the Greeks, Persians, Macedonians, Indians, Carthaginians, Romans, Gauls, Celts, and Huns.

"Imagine if Orville and Wilbur Wright did not successfully fly their powered airplane in 1903, but instead ten years later. In such an alternate history there would be no effective combat airplanes. Commitments in military research and industrial production might have instead, focused on the Zeppelin as a weapon carrier. This game provides a tactical simulation of such Zeppelin warfare."

link.value: Zeppelin Battles of the Great War

item.description:
"Skirmish is a game of warriors on the battleground fighting in the midst of chaos. Bodies lie everywhere, and there are enough of the armies remaining that none can retreat. Each warrior is without a side to aid them. All other players in the game are their enemy. The last warrior standing is the winner."

"Inspired by Atlas Games' Lunch Money."

The game is available on the author's website here-
http://www.curufea.com/games/skirmish/

"Shapeshifting wizards duel to the death, fight over magical artifacts or seek certain objectives."

"Every player starts with one Wizard. Each wizard is a Human with a pool of 50 Mana. Mana is used to cast spells, change shape, and activate special abilities of the shape the wizard is currently using. Mana can only be recovered in Human form, once per turn."

The game includes three scenarios:

"Dueling Wizards - Two age old rivals meet for a final showdown. "

"Wizard War - Rival kingdoms at war send their court mages to take care of the competition before invasion."

"The Key of Soloman - An artifact of power has been unearthed, the magical emanations in the ether have attracted treasure seeking wizards."

"Concept: A primarily two player game. One player is the owner of the mansion, the other is the thief. The owner spends resources to set up the mansion, and the thief tries to steal the treasured item. The behaviour of the guards in the mansion are mostly automated responses. If more than two players - then the additional players are additional thieves."

"Setting: The world of Thief is a steampunk setting. There are gas, coal, steam and some electrical powered machines. There is also some magic."

"Inspired by the various Thief games from Looking Glass Studios that have been part of my favourite computer games of all time."

"Much like the Incan Gold game (Diamant), it's a game of pushing your luck and knowing when to betray the other players to get away with as much gold as possible. Every turn a player decides whether to play a card to continue journeying into the caves, or to retreat with their current gains. The chances of dying and not making any money increases as players move further into the caves."

"The difference between this game and the original is that it uses normal playing cards, and there are more choices for the players involved."

The rules are available on the author's website here-
http://www.curufea.com/Wikka/wikka.php?wakka=MayanGold

"Card Game for 2 or more players. Players are 17th century alchemists, competing for the creation of the Philosophers Stone."

The game uses a custom deck containing three types of cards: Elements, Procedures, and Substances. Elements and Procedures must be combined to create Substances, which in turn can be combined with Elements, Procedures, or other Substances to create more complex Substances.

"The first player who creates the 'Resurrected Lapis Philosophorum' wins."

"This is a modifiable dungeon-crawling game for 2-4 players."

One player takes on the role of the Dungeon Master. The other players each control a Hero who is exploring the dungeon. The game uses three to five custom card decks: a DM Deck (60 cards), a Dungeon Deck (30 cards), and a Hero Deck for each Hero player (60 cards.)

The Dungeon Deck consists of cards specifying rooms and passages which are used to randomly create the dungeon. A Hero Deck consists of cards for various actions and treasures. The DM Deck consists primarily of cards representing monsters and traps.

The Hero players win if the Objective room card is located and resolved. The DM player wins if all of the Heroes are killed before they resolve the Objective room.

"This game simulates the growth of ancient empires. Each player leads a young empire and controls its growth through its development. The units used to represent people are populations and monetary units are measured in gold points."

"Use a piece of hex paper and color equal numbers of squares green for grassland and yellow for desert. Each player chooses a starting grassland hex and puts a city and 3 population points on that hex. No two starting hexes may be closer than three hexes from each other."

The players build their empires by constructing cities, roads, temples, walls, marketplaces, and libraries. There are also three types of military forces available to attack opposing empires: Soldiers, Swordsmen, and Horsemen. The game also covers concepts such as disasters, technological advances, taxes, and population migration.

"Victory occurs when, at the end of his turn, a player has 20 victory points or has destroyed or captured all enemy cities, armies and populations." Victory Points are scored for cities, temples, and technological advances.

"Solo Crusade is a simple set of rules to play a solo adventure with your favourite RPG. The underlying idea is very simple: one or more pools of 'tiles' are used to represent the map, the encounters, the events and in general every possible obstacle/help during your quest."

"Using a pool of tiles rather than simply roll some dices to create the adventure has a some major of advantages"

"• Visual representation of your travel: the tiles played on the table are much more " satisfactory" than a never-ending sequence of dice rolls."

"• Better control of the random factor: you can have tiles that can be drawn only once, tiles that are replaced when played."

This set of rules allows you to play out solo RPG adventures on the tabletop, similar to games such as DeathMaze and the Metagaming MicroQuests series. The rules include tables and instructions for four sample adventures: The Wilderness, Hobgoblin Forest, Hunt for the Tribe, and the Black Pit.

An antique spin-and-move board game themed around a hurdle race.

The components include a spinner, four different colored wooden pawns, and the box (which has the board mounted inside the bottom and the rules printed inside the lid.) In the race around the board, the players must clear three hurdles, two water jumps, and avoid a marauding bull.

Publication date is approximate.


 Lid text includes "It Is Great Sport/Milton Bradley Co. Springfield, Mass." 
 Milton Bradley inhouse art depicting Buster and Tige, Foxy Grandpa, one of Katzenjammer Kids on lid.
 Inside board has animals and humans w/recognizable characters of Buster, Katzenjammer, Foxy Grandpa, Happy Hooligan and Gloomy Gus, Black character likely representing Pore Lil' Mose and four human or animal characters inspired by Swinnerton. 
 Instructions on inside lid w/© 1905. 
 3.25 x 3.25" spinner

"Card game for 2 players. Setting: Turn of the Century United States. One player takes the role of Edison. The other player takes the role of Tesla."

Each round the players start by building their hands. The players alternate selecting one Research card from a set turned face up on the table. The players then to play melds of cards. A meld becomes a part of the player's Victory Pile.

"Victory: The player to score the most total Invention Points worth of Primary Cards in their victory pile at the end of 4 Rounds wins."

A card game of warring Ninja clans in Feudal Japan. The object of the game is to be the last surviving clan, or to have the highest ranking Ninja when there are no cards left in the deck.

The game uses a custom card deck which is composed of two types of cards - Ninja Cards and Event Cards. A player must recruit Ninjas and then send them on missions against opposing villages and Ninjas.

"Board game for 2-4+ players. Players are caravan merchants carrying goods back and Forth between China and Arabia."

"The Board: The board consists of a track 9 spaces long. The leftmost space is Arabia. The rightmost space is China. Arabia and China are referred to as destination spaces. The 7 intervening spaces are called road spaces."

"The Deck: Players share a common deck. There four main types of cards: Imports (Goods from Arabia), Exports (Goods from China), Road (Terrain along the Silk Road), Special (Obstacles and Opportunities)"

"Money in the game is counted in units of coins. The first player to accumulate 25 coins is the winner."

"Each player takes the role of a Soviet Sniper during WWII."

"Each player has 3 stats: Shoot, Hunt, and Evade. Shoot is needed to kill Targets. Hunt is needed to find Targets. Evade is used to survive Danger. Players start with a score of 5 in each Stat."

"Players share a common deck. The Deck has 4 types of Cards: Targets, Danger, Aid, and Nothing cards."

"The Game ends when all but one player has been killed, or the Deck has been completely used up. The player with the most Kill Stars at the end of the game wins."

"Card & Record Keeping Game for 2-4+ players. Each player is a European Imperial Power circa 1500-1750."

The players seek to conquer 40 territories spread across five regions: the Caribbean, South America, Central America, North America, and Canada. Rather than relying on a map board, each territory is represented by a card in the Exploration Deck.

Players can gain control of territories through colonization or military conquest. The capability to do so depends on successful production and trade efforts, which provide the resources required to raise armies, build ships, and hire workers. The players must also be ready to cope with random events, such as piracy, storms, and revolutions.

"Card Game for 2 players. WII with Wonder Weapons and the Occult as the main determinants of victory."

"One players is the Allies. The other is the Germans."

"Players have scores in 9 Stats. These stats are increased/decreased during play. Players begin with scores in each stat as listed on the Starting Stat Chart."

The nine Stats are: Intelligence, Attack, Occult, Research, Propaganda, Morale, Force, Economy, and Defense. The Allied Player and the German Player start the game with specified Stat scores.

"You win if you reduce your opponent to zero Morale or zero Force."

"Card Game for 2 players. Theme: The Satsuma Rebellion in Japan in 1877. The Modern Imperial Army destroyed the last of the Samurai. One player is the Samurai. The other player is the Imperial Army."

The game uses two custom decks of cards, the Samurai Deck and the Imperial Deck. Each deck contains eight types of cards, each ranked with a Strength value: Force, Reserves, Leader, Attack, Defense, Morale, Weapons, and Escape.

"The game ends when the Samurai player has accumulated 9 Casualty Markers. At that point, the last of the Samurai have been wiped out. Victory is a function of how many casualties the Samurai were able to inflict on the Imperials."

"Card game for 2 players. Theme: New Zealand Maori Wars 1840-1872. One player is the Pakehas (White Men). The other player is the Native Maori."

The game uses a set of 19 Land Tokens and two custom decks of cards - a Maori Deck and a Pakehas Deck. There are nine different types of cards, each named for aspects of the conflict (Leaders, Tactics, Weapons, Politics, Morale, Defenses, etc.) Each card is ranked with a Strength value from 2 to 5.

Each hand the players battle for the possession of a single Land Token. Tokens are won by playing a set of cards having a higher total Strength value than those played by the opponent. The first player to acquire ten Land Tokens wins the game.

"Area Control game for 2-6 players. Early Earth Primitive Microbial Life Forms Compete for Territory." Each player represents one of six different Microbial Kingdoms which have special attributes or abilities.

The game is played on a map composed of 64 Territories. Each space on the board has a set resource value from 0 to 5. The resource value governs the maximum number of Biomass Tokens that may occupy the Territory at the end of each turn.

"The Game ends when all territories are filled up to their 
Max population levels." Victory Points are then awarded based on factors such as the number of Territories a player controls and the number of Biomass Tokens each player has in play. The player with the most Victory Points wins the game.

"Strategy Card and Board Game for 2 to 6+ players. It is the Warm Permian-Triassic period and primitive animals are just starting to colonize the landmass of Pangaea."

Every player controls one of ten "Basic Taxons" representing a group of prehistoric animals. Each Taxon has a special ability.

The object of the game is to have the most Victory Points after every Territory on the board is occupied at least one Animal Token. Victory Points are awarded at the end of the game based on the number of Animal Tokens a player has on the board, as well as the number of Territories occupied exclusively by the player.

"Card, Bidding, and Stock Ownership Game for 2-6+ players."

"Each player is a large Multinational Corporation. 
Players invest in different World Powers."

"World Powers represent Nations and whole Regions. 
There are 9 different World Powers players can invest in."

"The basic monetary unit is the Treasury Token. The player with the most Treasury Tokens at the end of the game is the winner."

"Bidding game for 3-5 players. Each player is an Imperialist Power in the late Nineteenth Century trying to get a piece of China." Each player plays one of five Imperialist Powers: Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and Japan. Each country has a unique special bonus.

The game is played using two shared card decks - the Territory Deck and the Imperial Deck. The game ends when there are no cards left in the Territory Deck. The winner is the player having the most Victory Points, as determined by the combined point total of the Territory Cards in the player's Victory Pile.

"The game is a simulation of the hardships faced by the first English Colonists to the New World in the 1600s. Each player controls their own colony, modeled after Jamestown, the Plymouth Pilgrims, and the Boston Puritans." The game consists of six card decks: a Leader Deck, Site Deck, Action Deck, Build Deck, Food Deck, and Hardships Deck.

"The game lasts 5 years. This represents the first 5 years of each players colony. Each Season is a turn, so the game runs for 20 turns."

"Victory: The player with the most Victory Points (VP) at the end of the game wins." Victory Points are scored for the number of Colonist Tokens, Land Purchase Tokens, and Buildings a player possesses at the end of the game.

"The Spanish Empire: 15-18th Centuries. Each player is a Noble Family in Spain, trying to serve the Crown by arranging the loans and manpower to fight the Wars and Discover, conquer, and exploit new lands in the name of Empire."

Description extrapolated from TheBigGameHunter.com:

ZULU BLOW GUN GAME (1925, Zulu Game Co., Battle Creek, Michigan) comes from a category of games no longer available: the "projectile" game. Safety requirements have virtually eliminated all sharp, pointed projectiles from games (other than DARTS), and although the packaging on the ZULU BLOW GUN GAME states "harmless," the game's bamboo dart, when made airborne from the blowgun, could pierce many things, including body parts. Object was to score points by hitting different valued targets using the blowgun and bamboo darts.
Childs game which features animal sounds which must be matched to the animal pictures in order to score points.

Roll and move game from the 1960's. More info on how to play the game to follow. Game features a playing board, 4 plastic men and 2 dice.

The game is about two clan chieftains fighting for territory.

The winning player is the Chieftain whose eventual strength of territories, Clansmen and dues, defeats all other players by surviving until all the other Chieftains lose all of their territories.

It was designed and published by Marketplan for the House of Seagram, to promote Seagram's 100 Pipers brand of Scotch whisky.

name.value: Defenders of the Earth Giant Card Game

item.description: Children's card game featuring the actions of Superheroes as they try to defend Earth from invading aliens. The object of the game is to collect 10 or more Hero points before collecting 10 villian points. There are Power Of Evil cards that may be used to cancel out the point value of any one Hero Card diplayed by an opponent. If you accumulate 10 Villian Points you are immediately out of the game.

name.value: The Chisholm Trail from Texas to Dodge City

item.description: The object of the game is for each player to get his herd of 1,000 head of Texas Longhorn cattle up the "The Chisholm Trail" to Dodge City, Kansas. The game comes with a game board, a spinner, 4 metal longhorn tokens, 6 blue cards, 6 red cards, a pad of tally sheets, & a rule book

You try to circle Wide Track Drive in Pontiac, Michigan in this game created to promote the host city of Superbowl XVI. The game was created by I&I Game Inventors of Pontiac, MI. and is copyrighted - 1981. The object of the game is to be the first player to circle Wide Track Drive, the main road in Pontiac, while being sidetracked along the journey by drawing instruction cards directing you to various venues of the city such as the mall, Church's lumber, Lupe's restaurant, Pontiac police station, Pontiac High school, the Silverdome etc.

"Generic rule set for a series of empire building/conquest games."

Games designed to be played using the Warp Empires system are called Warp Empires modules. Each module describes the units and other components needed to play the module.

Warp Empires modules are generally played on a map composed of irregular areas or territories. Counters are used to represent units, items, and control markers.

Card play is central to the system. One or more Action Decks are used in each module. Action Cards are played to move units or stacks. In addition, some Action Cards provide benefits in combat.

Victory conditions generally involve controlling a certain number of territories or destroying all opposing forces, as specified in the individual Warp Empires module.

The following games use the Warp Empires system:


 Babylon 5 Empires
 Conquest of Demara
 Dark Sun Empires
 Doctor Who Empires
 Doom Trooper Empires



 Empires of Mystara
 Europe at War
 Federation
 Land War in Asia
 Lord of the Abyss



 Middle Earth Empires
 Scortch
 Space 1889 Empires
 Star Wars Campaign
 Union & Confederacy



 Warcraft Empires
 War Hammer Space Empires
 War of Independence
 Warp Hammer Empires

name.value: Rules of the Road: Seamanship Cards

item.description: This card game was (from info on the box) put out by Noble and Noble and prepared by Lt. Comdr. W.D. Kipp. Object of the game is to navigate your ship by making use of correct whistle and fog cards and also by making correct use of International, Inland and Pilot Rules to safely complete your trip.

"Card game for 2-6 players. Each player takes the role of a prominent citizen of a newly founded Greek Colony. Players make money (Drachmas) by trading goods at the market (Agora). They then use this money to construct the important buildings of their Fledgling City State."

The game includes two card decks, the Agora Deck and the Build Deck.

The 48 card Agora Deck contains cards representing goods that can be traded in the marketplace. There are four cards for each of the twelve types of commodities.

The 15 card Build Deck contains cards from the three types of Construction Categories: Military, Civic, and Religious.

"The game ends when all 15 cards of the Build deck have been claimed. At the end of the game, the player who has the highest score in the most Construction Categories wins."

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Napoleon Dynamite School Election Theme. Each player has a 'Nerdy' candidate that is running for school president."

Each player tracks three statistics: Time, Money, and Votes. Card play can add to your stats and cause an opponent's stats to decrease. In addition, some cards require that the play incur a time or money loss in order to be played.

"The game ends at the end of the turn in which the last card has been drawn from the deck. The player with the most votes at the end of the game wins."

A card game themed around the Chakras. The game uses a custom card deck consisting of 49 cards in seven suits. Each suit is made up of seven cards, one for each Chakra.

The players score points by playing a combos. There are five types of combos, each of which scores either 3 or 7 Chakra Points. The winner is the player who has scored the most Chakra Points after seven combos have been played.

Hexway The New Game from the AHOY Series of games produced by Robert Ross and Co. LTD is advertised as a game that is simple enough for children and subtle enough for grownups. The game appears to be a tile laying game where a road and houses are constructed from hexes. No other information is available at this time but the game is presently being researched.

Alternardo is a horse racing game that comes with a folding board and six horse cards. The players each choose a card and lay it on the right place on the board, then follow the instructions which move the horses around the track by differing amounts.

Re-implemented by:
Also Ran

Card game for 2-4+ players. Based on the growth of Industry in the Severn Gorge in England at the beginning of the 1700’s, The Birthplace of the Industrial Revolution. Each player is an Ironmaster who controls a company in the region. Players buy cards that represent mines, refineries, factories, and other resources. These resources produce income. Players score Victory points each turn if they are the leader in a certain type of industry. A copy of the rules is available for free at: 
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/IBG.html

name.value: Cadbury's Milk Tray Man In Black Game

item.description:
From the box cover:

"Cadbury's Milk Tray MAN IN BLACK Game - an exciting and sophisticated game of skill, nerve and strategy for 2-4 players.

Players become the mysterious 'Man In Black' and:
- encounter landslides, avalanches and floods!
- block your opponents and deliver the box of Milk Tray
- make incredible get-aways by car or helicopter"

The game was produced by Waddington's games in the UK as a promotional item for Cadbury's "Milk Tray" chocolates. The advertising campaign for Milk Tray featured arguably the most famous advertising character in British TV history, the Milk Tray Man, a pseudo James Bond character who performed several death defying feats in order to deliver a box of chocolates.

Game contents:
- 1 plastic playing area, in two parts
- 76 hexagonal route tiles
- 4 "Men In Black" playing pieces
- 4 helicopters
- 4 getaway cars
- 6 getaway route tiles (double sided)
- 4 landslide markers
- 4 tree markers
- 1 "Man In Black" trump tile
- 1 "Lady" tile
- 1 "Start" tile
- dice and shaker

The object of the game is for each player to race their individual "Man In Black" piece from the Start hexagon tile, across the playing area, and to the Lady hexagon tile.

Each player is dealt 5 route tiles, a "Man In Black" playing piece, a getaway car piece and a helicopter piece.

On their turn, each player has the choice of either placing a Route tile on the board, or throwing a dice to see how many squares they can move their piece along already placed Route tiles.

Each route tile features a different road segment marked with squares. Some squares feature hazards which delay the player. Route tiles can be placed in any position, at any time throughout the game, on each players turn.

The getaway car, helicopter, landslide and tree markers can be used to move the players piece further, or to obstruct other players.

Game components consist of quality heavy duty card tiles, a moulded plastic board, and hand painted pieces.

The game is notable for being one of the earliest examples of a tile laying game, with each game producing a new road layout for players to travel.

The goal of Pyramid Power is to play all of your Pyramid tiles and to score points. A pyramid tile is a triangular tile with each corner of the triangle being one color.

When a Pyramid tile is played, the corner colors must match the corner colors of tiles already played. Players score the value of the tile played. If the Pyramid tile matches on the more than one side, bonuses are scored.

If a player has unplayable tiles, the player draws one tile to try and play. The first player to play all of their Pyramid tiles ends the game and scores as a bonus the value of the other players remaining Pyramid tiles. High score is the winner.

Noar is a 2 player strategy board-game, that combines elements of Morris & Reversi, and is played on a Hypercube Board. Players take turns moving a piece , along the lines of the board, to a adjacent unoccupied spaces. The object of the game is to capture the other players piece by flanking it with two of your pieces.

Simple "roll and move" game, where players travel around world and learn geography. First part of game consists traveling through all continents and second part is a trivia of a geography learned when traveling.

Published in Games Magazine in September 2008, Alfred's Wyke is a two player game where one plays the Builder, the other the Destroyer. Square tiles are place in 2×2 plots that are arranged on a 4×4 grid (except for one pair of opposite corners that start with just 3 tiles). The Builder tries to build up two-story "houses" (2×2×2), while the Destroyer tries completely demolish buildings in order to create empty plots (2×2×0). On each turn, the players select from a menu of five tile placement/removal options:

 1-1-1-1-1 (one at each of five different plots) Note: If and only if each player has claimed six plots, meaning only four plots remain unclaimed, this option becomes 1-1-1-1.
 2-1-1 (two at one plot; one at each of two others)
 2-2 (two at each of two plots)
 3-1 (three at one plot; one at another)
 4 (four at one plot)




However, after each player has taken one turn, only three are available on any turn, because a player cannot pick a set that has been selected in the previous two turns. Once a plot is completely built or torn down, it is claimed by a player. The first player to claim one of the following wins the game:

 four plots in a row (orthogonally or diagonally)
 four plots in a 2×2 square
 four more plots than his opponent
 a total of seven plots

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The object of this educational game is to enter Jerusalem and place a 'Note' in the Kotel (the Western Wall).

The board is a (disproportionate) map of Israel and is broken up into 7 regions. When a player passes through each of the first 6 regions, they earn the corresponding Activity Diploma that is required to enter the final Jerusalem region.

Depending on the space that the player lands on, they must either: 1) Answer a question; or, 2) Draw a Yesh/Gevalt card and follow the instructions.

By answering the trivia questions, players learn about Israeli history, Hebrew, Judaism, Jewish heritage, and Jewish traditions.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Object of the game is to be the first to build a 1000 Megawatt Nuclear Reactor. Players move around a foldable, washable polyester "board" laid out in a Monopoly style format. Money and Generating Capacity are tracked by moving tokens on the side of the board. Game includes 25 Hazard and Scram cards. Players roll two dice (three for expert players) but move only the amount of one die at a time.

Messengers must reach the king's palace. There are Kahuna cards, Messengers, Tributes, Tiki cards, Aina cards. Board game shows the islands of Hawaii. Points accumulated determine the winner. Advanced variation of the game involves a battle in which chiefs gain land on the islands.

name.value: Cluedo: Le Jeu des Grands Détectives
Cluedo: Scopri tutti i misteri di Tudor Hall
妙探尋兇: 發掘真相

item.description:
This has been carried over from the original Clue (also known as Cluedo):
A person card, a weapon card, and a room card is removed from the deck and placed in an envelope. That envelope is placed in the center of the gameboard. The rest of the deck is shuffled and distributed to the players as evenly as possible. Each player now assumes the role of one of the suspects. The object of the game is to deduce which are the missing cards. In turn, the players will roll the dice and move their pawns to various rooms. Once in a room, the player may float a rumor as to which are the missing cards. If the person to the rumormonger’s immediate left can disprove the rumor by showing one of the cards mentioned, then the player must secretly reveal the card. Play continues until one person can identify the missing cards correctly, that person is the winner.

The version’s additions:
Each person has been given a unique power which may be used only once per game. There is an Intrigue deck which may or may not grant a player an extra action. Those Intrigue cards which do not grant an extra action are called Clock Cards. The player who draws the eighth Clock card is eliminated from play. Any player who draws a Clock Card thereafter is also eliminated. The “one” on one of the dice has been replaced by “?”. Any player who rolls “?” must draw an Intrigue card.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A simple tactical wargame covering the battles of Swiss Middle Ages: Morgarten 1315, Sempach 1386 and Grandson 1476.

One map hexagon represents about 200 meters and each game turn represents about 1/2 hour of real time.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Po Stopach Izenyru Hanzelky a Zykmunda z Prahy do Kapskeho mesta Osmickou Tatrou

item.description:
Name of the game is really that long, it means translated:
"Following the paths of the engineers Hanzelka and Zykmund from Prague to Capetown with the 8-cylinder Tatra".

The engineers were employees of the Tatra Motor Works in Czecho then, and in times when car driving was still an adventure, especially in Africa, they made this journey to demonstrate the durability of their famous streamline car, the Tatra 87.

The journey lasted from 1947 to 1949, and was full of incidents.

Even some books about it were published, and this game followed.

The game is extremely scarce, and what makes it special is that the wooden game pawns are shaped like the abovementioned streamline car.

The rest is pure nostalgia, roll-and-move and some card-drafting.

Box and gameboard are extremely large: Box measures 20 x 15 inches, the board is 4 times as large !!!

From the packaging:

Think you know WWE?

Prove yourself in an extreme battle to become the No. 1 ranked Superstar in WWE. Watch and answer 5 different categories of on-screen DVD challenges featuring all of your favorite WWE Superstars & Legends.

Synopsis:
Answer questions presented by the DVD. Answering correctly moves you up the game board. Answering incorrectly moves you down the game board. The first player to reach the end of the board wins.

name.value: Jeu du code de la route

item.description:
Contents : a special dice (with two stars), a printed board showing the map of a town with holes at the crossroads, two disks printed on both sides with different crossroads that you can fix under the board, a policeman pawn , two errand boy paws, two errand girl pawns, cards with errand orders, cards for bikes, money coins and bills.

The game is intended to teach kids the highway code. The players try to accomplish errand orders in order to win money quicker than the others, but they must respect the highway code or they will end at the hospital. The crossroads patterns can be changed quickly, and the policeman appears in a sudden to check if the bikes are in good state. The first to collect 20 euros and to get back to the concert hall wins the game.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Hekumanhuippu (engl. Climax) is an erotic game for two lovers.

Players roll a die and move on a board with separate tracks for both towards the end, the climax. The tracks consist of four kind of points: Truth, Dare, Strip and Volcano. When a player enters a point (s)he must draw a corresponding action card from a pile, read it aloud and perform the given action. Some actions are quite innocuous, some bolder (especially in the endgame).

On both tracks there are a few points where players have to take a longer reroute, throw a die again or stop (ie. perform no action). If a player throws a six, (s)he must take six steps backwards making the game last even longer.

The player to reach the end (climax) first is the winner. (S)he may choose the prize or players can decide it together beforehand.

Contents:
-Game board
-47 Truth cards
-45 Dare cards
-12 Strip cards
-19 Volcano cards
-Two pawns
-A die
-Rules printed at the bottom of the box
Mikkelipeli ("The Mikkeli Game") is a promotive game designed for the Finnish town of Mikkeli. The mechanics resemble Monopoly but a deck of Mikkeli oriented quiz cards has been added.

name.value: Formosa Rail: 1899 from North to South

item.description:
Formosa Rail simulates ten years of railroad construction in Taiwan, bringing rapid ground transportation from north to south. Each player acts as one of the architects collecting five sources then constructs in four possible sites. Construction includes demolishing, tunnel and bridge building and track and station building. Player receives victory points for every construction and bonus victory point for most construction within a site. At the end of the game, player with the highest victory point wins.

Player: 2 to 5
Ages 8 and up
Time: 90 to 120 minutes

Contents:
1) 5 Player's token in 5 colors
2) 6 Player's Tile Card (3 triangle, 2 square and 1 pentagon)
3) 80 resource cards (17 labor, 15 iron, 9 rock, 21 wood, 16 brick, and 2 TNT cards)
4) 23 building cards (7 different buildings)
5) 18 building markers (3 different markers)
6) 1 round wooden marker
7) 22 rail tracks wooden stick
8) 8 landscape square wooden tile (2 mountain, 3 river, 3 forest)
9) 5 player's aid cards
10) 1 game board
11) 1 rulebook

Publisher: Academia Historica (www.drnh.gov.tw)
Production: 2Plus Studio (www.2plus.com.tw)
Designer: Ta-Te Wu, Jong Kong, and Sheries Liu

Published in 1941 by Der Adler, the Luftwaffe (German Air Force) illustrated magazine, this easy children game see the two players sending their aircraft to bomb enemy targets. No need for a die - a spinner in the corner gives the random number for movement. This is a little game similar to richer boxed games from the same period as Adler Luftkampfspiel and Adler Luftverteidigungsspiel.

This card came consists of 6 suits of cards; Red, Blue, Green, Black, Yellow, and Orange. Each suit consists of 8 cards, with point values from 1-8. Each of the 8 cards also have images of camping-related items on their faces, one such image per card, with no duplicates in each suit.
There are also 3 "wild cards."

Thus the deck consists of 51 cards, and each card has a color, point value from 1-8, and image. (with the exception of the 3 wild cards)

The goal of the game is to collect a set of cards that meets one of the following criteria:
A) 7 cards with the same color borders (suited)
B) 6 cards with the same image (which requires one from each suit)
c) 60 points worth of cards.

Wild cards can be any color or item, but will always be 0 points.

Hand size is 8 cards. On a player's turn, they may either draw a card from the deck and discard from their hand, or offer a trade with another player. Hand management is important, as is tracking what other players are trying to collect in order to block them if possible.

A nice tile-laying game where the goal is to make the longest snake possible, but it's not quite that simple. Snakes are built in various colors, and body sections can be added that match. Players can catch snakes that have a head and at least two body parts, but longer snakes are worth more points. So the idea is to wait long enough to get good points, but not so long that someone else catches the snake you've been building up. The first player to catch a snake gets the "snake bracelet", and they wear this until a snake of a longer length is caught. The person wearing the bracelet at the game's end gets bonus points in addition to their snake points.

This set of rules supports ancients, medievals and fantasy campaigns with 15mm and 25mm miniatures. The sections on Logistics and Disease make you think more like an actual field commander. Your troops cannot fight well if they don't have any food or get sick. Your lines of supply suddenly become more important, and you cannot cram your fortress with too many men.

Rules sections include: Introduction; Scales; Movement; Siege Engines; Other Weapons; Mining; Protective Devices; Engineering; Defenders - Attackers; Magic; Logistics; The Last Resort

Battle of the River Plate is a two player card game themed on the WWII sea battle of the same name.

One player represents the Kriegsmarine and the other player the Royal Navy.

Through careful card play, players build sets of cards that represent attacks by the various ships that took part in the battle.

It is a free Print and Play game web published by BookRanger.

This is a very simple collectible card game that comes with Chipsmore cookies sold in Malaysia. A pack of Chipsmore cookies comes with 3 different random cards, which are in both English and Malay.

The objective of the game is to play all your cards. All players start with the same number of cards. There is no limit, except for the minimum of 6 cards. The core game is in the Action Cards, which you use to ask your opponents to do various physical actions, e.g. hopping on one foot. There are also Booster Cards, Mirror Cards, Counter Cards and Magical Cards, each with different powers.

Mingle - Dice of Diction
Dice of Diction is the slogan that appears on the box top of this made-in-Malaysia letter-dice game.

The game comes with 8 letter-dice, each letter having its own point-score indicated next to it. There is also a 3-minute sand-timer and a pad of scoring diagrams for players to use.

Two games may be played with this set (and one of these two games may itself be played in two ways).

Mingle-Crossword makes use of the scoring diagram - each player gets one sheet of score pad with a 17 X 17 square grid on it (and space for writing down the scores). Each turn, the 8 dice are cast and the timer started. Players then have until the timer runs out to form a word using two or more of the eight letters showing. This first word must cover the centre square. Play continues, with each player forming words that intersect crossword-style with existing words on their own diagram. The diagram contains shaded squares that when used result in double or quadruple letter scores or double or quadruple word scores. After a fixed number of words (say 25), players total up their scores and the highest score wins.

Mingle-Listing is simply a game of anagramming letters that come up on the eight dice when thrown. The first way to play is simply to throw the dice, set the timer going and for each player to list out as many words as he/she can. The player who lists the most words, wins. The second way of playing is to have players take turns to state a new word that can be formed from the dice. When a player cannot state a new word, he/she loses and drops out. The remaining players cast the dice again and play continues until only one player remains.

This game is probably no longer in print as it is not mentioned in SPM's current website.

The Heineken Spin-sation! Game was used as a premium gift in a marketing campaign by Heineken in Singapore during the Christmas season (17 Nov to 21 Dec) in 2007. People who bought Heineken beer gained points and these points could be exchanged for premiums like T-shirts, bags, sound speakers, calendars and this game.

The game itself is completely random. Players spin a cardboard wheel affixed to a board; the board also has spaces to place 4 stacks of cards. Depending on which segment on the wheel ends up next to where the picture of the beer bottle is pointing, the player who spun the wheel draws a chance card, which gives the player positive or negative points. The card may also have instructions or forfeits for the player to follow.

The four types of cards are:

1) Let's celebrate cards
These all give the player +40 points. There's also a date of some festival on the card with some advice for the player.

E.g. +40 points. February 5th (2008) Mardi Gras, New Orleans. Don't come back without some beach.

2) Oops! cards
These all give the player -10 points and have an action for the player to carry out.

E.g. -10 points. Collect an Oops! card from every girl.

3) Spin-sation! cards
These all give the player =10 points and have a forfeit for the player to perform.

E.g. -10 points. Tell a joke that no one in the room has heard before.

4) Heineken cards
These all give the player +20 points and have an action for the player to carry out (always a good thing).

E.g. +20 points. Take 3 Heineken cards from the player on your right.

The game ends whenever any stack of cards on the board is used up. Players then tally their nett scores and the player with the most points wins. The player with the least number of points has to perform the Ultimate Forfeit (sic), which the winner decides.

A bloody game. Your goal is to be absolutely awesome. Jump through windows with a sword in one hand and a trash can in the other... Throw it at your enemy and watch one of his arms fall off, but wait pick that up to and beat your next opponent with! So long as blood is being spilled and baddies are dying it doesn't matter.

Blood is a stylized tongue and cheek cinematic action game.

The Great War is an A4 soft back with 160 pages, lavishly illustrated in colour with plenty of photographs of the armies for reference when painting and collecting.

When war broke out in August 1914, the majority of military commanders felt that the war would be over by Christmas. The early clashes developed into huge offensives all ending in stalemate. 
Battlefield technology and tactics evolved at a spectacular pace with the tank, airplane support and coordinated bombardment becoming commonplace. 
As 1918 dawned these new weapons of war spearheaded the offensives, but it was still the soldier’s war to win or lose, where men endured heroically under fire.

The Great War rulebook contains the following: 
• A brief historical overview. 
• Western Front 1914 and 1918 British, French and German Battalion level army lists. 
• Sample army rosters so you can start collecting and playing quickly. 
• Standard and Operational Missions. 
• Inspiring photographs of the armies for reference when painting and collecting.

The Great War core rulebook is the first in a series enabling gamers to recreate the conflicts of World War One on the table-top.
